data.message: That degree in Ancient Celtic Cobbling will never pay off.

at 18 and 19 years old I don't think most kids can look that far ahead-believe me even though I was educated at two private colleges I am already telling my kids about the solid education a state school can provide!  I agree it's unreal to agree to that much debt when you aren't even sure what you will be doing with the rest of your life and if you will have the means to pay it

Even the current unemployment rate, if broken down by education level, shows that those with a college degree or higher are the least unemployed.  The other thing is that those with college degrees earn more money than those who don't.  You can find this information on the u.s. labor dept. website (i have looked it up in the past but am too lazy at the moment to link here).  So, knowing that, why wouldn't one get a degree?  (I am an anomaly as until recently I didn't have a degree and earned six figures - but i'm in the computer field, which is probably where you see this anomaly more frequently).  State schools are great.  Umass Lowell offers free tuition for community college transfers if they went to one of the state community colleges and maintained a 3.0, for example.  Not the "conventional" way to get into a four year college, but definitely has been for many people (comm -> four year).  But yes, to pay that much money when you aren't even sure what you want to do.....  finally, there are some careers where a college degree doesn't matter and you can make good money (e.g. plumber, electrician, etc.).  Melissa - tell your kids that Jack Welch went to a state school (UMASS) and if any of them are football fans, the current NFL commissioner went to a UMASS school.  :)

I have a hard time having much empathy for those with huge student loan debt. They went to private schools, often to obtain degrees with poor employment prospects, often for more than four years, took out significant loans for living expenses, and often did not even work summers. Yeah, it sucks to be saddled with lifelong debt because you made bad decisions at age 18. But should the guy who went into the military because he was smart enough to know he couldn't otherwise afford school then have to further subsidize the years you spent throwing pots and reading Proust?
Sarah, you say basically what I was thinking but was too politic to blurt out. (Though I don't see how the military guy is subsidizing their education...)

A lot of people are asking for student loan forgiveness. That money would be coming from all of us.

Perhaps all student loan documentation should include a statement of the median starting salary and likelihood of employment in the student's chosen field of study. It seems like a lot of people feel like they've been tricked, like they expected their BFAs to pay off or something. Explicitly including that statement (perhaps with amortization figures, to show how many years it will take them to pay off their loans at that expected salary?) should prevent that at least.

I do feel for current/ recent graduates; when I graduated even sociology majors could get jobs. There isn't a heck of a lot out there right now. It's time for a new WPA (which would also reduce our current social obligation to pay unemployment benefits for years).
Maybe a basic requirement to get into a college would be to figure it out yourself.

As I look at this more, I'm beginning to think that predatory lending is afoot here. You'd think that it would pay for lenders to try to educate those they lend to about their obligations. I think they would do so if there were actual risk in taking uninformed people onto their liabilities line.

Student loan "forgiveness" doesn't have to come from the taxpayer. For typical loans, lenders are not bailed out by with tax dollars when someone can't pay what they owe. That said, one could easily believe that if there were debt forgiveness, that the gov't would be pressed very hard by the finance industry to cough up cash. It certainly did so in 2008.

I'd also like to see a new WPA. It seems like win-win to me, but the pessimism and jadedness of people regarding "big government" makes it seem like a non-starter.

Having paid a lot in student loans once I got my masters and a career I will say the other thing I will be steering my kids away from is a "liberal arts" degree.  Yes I want my kids to go to college both for the education and the experience but I want them to go with a goal in mind.  My first four very expensive years were spent deciding what I wanted to do next-fortunately I chose a masters program and career that I still have a passion for which brings me to my last point; they ultimately have to enjoy and be proud of what they do...with that, paying the loans just feels like repaying a good investment.  Without it-well that I can't imagine!

With regard to student loan forgiveness...I'm sure there are situations where it is warranted but you'd hate to see people using it like so many do bankruptcy-as a way to escape from their own poor financial choices. Responsibility hmmm

description: One of the most fascinating things to come out of the current We Are 99%/Occupy Wall Street protests is the We Are 99% Tumblr.  At the site, people hold up signs that explain their current circums...
message:
Interesting stats gleaned from the "We are 99%" website.

As an aside, I find myself shocked by the debt many have racked up for education. First off, I was unaware education became so incredibly expensive. (Its increase sounds as disappointingly unwarranted and unexplainable as the increase in health care costs.) Secondly, how can anyone go into so much debt with their eyes open? I admit that I've been very debt-averse my whole life but still I can't believe how far under water these people are; even a good salary wouldn't pay off their education bills for years and years and years.
name: Parsing the Data and Ideology of the We Are 99% Tumblr
